repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Social Security Special Sector
            Adjustment Loan (SS SECAL)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, and, despite delays in the legislative
            process, the Borrower fully complied with the conditions of
            the loan. While sustainability is likely, it is however
            subject to a number of risks, namely, the need for further
            reforms, and, a new course remains to be charted for a
            viable retirement security system, that encourages private
            savings. The key lessons convey that: 1) the analytical
            tools applied, allowed the Borrower to conduct its own
            analysis, and, staff trained in the use of simulation
            models, both quantified liabilities, and determined optimal
            reform strategies. This approach is considered critical in
            mobilizing essential resource support for future amendments
            to the Constitution, and further structural reforms; 2) the
            politics of social security reform should be considered
            early, to prod a fruitful dialogue, as in this case, the
            support to provide only modest improvements to the reformed
            pension system, as requested by the Government, allowed
            greater influence on the formulation of future reforms; 3)
            comprehensive public awareness is critical for successful
            social insurance, and pension reforms, though information on
            fiscal imbalances of pension systems alone, is not enough,
            for, inevitably it will hinder the Administration's
            reform strategy; and, 4) the selection of a single-tranche
            adjustment instrument, was appropriate, given the
            politically sensitive policy agenda.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Social Security Special Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Security Special Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project will be the first of two sector
            adjustment loans in support of Brazil's Social Security
            Reform Program. The first loan will support the first phase
            of the Social Security Reform Program. The first phase of
            the reform consists of a constitutional amendment to modify
            clauses of the Federal Constitution of 1988 dealing with
            Social Security, to: a) introduce the principle of actuarial
            balance; b) replace retirement based on length of service
            with length of contribution; c) eliminate specific benefit
            rules from the Federal Constitution; d) eliminate most
            special pension regimes; and e) reduce inequalities between
            benefits of public and private sector workers. The first
            risk of this loan is that the legislature may not approve
            the imposition of higher pension contributions and income
            taxes on the politically powerful public sector workers and
            retirees. The Government has tried to mitigate this risk by
            widely publicizing the inequities and abuse of the system.
            Another risk is that states and municipalities may refuse to
            accept either the limits on their ability to establish their
            own pension systems or the requirement to introduce
            automatic adjustments in contributions when net pension
            payments exceed a determined share of current revenues. This
            risk is mitigated by reinforcing Federal controls over state
            and municipal expenditure on salaries and pensions.
